\begin{document}

\title{Literature review of Charney--Phillips and Lorenz staggering}
\author{Hilary Weller}
\date{May 2015}
\maketitle

\begin{itemize}

\item \bibentry{HTW13a} \ \\
Charney Philips even best when including a boundary layer. But energy conservation is a bit more difficult
\item \bibentry{HTW13b}
\item \bibentry{AK96} \ \\
Description of the grids in $\sigma$ coordinates\\
Vertical slice test cases to excite computational modes\\
Baroclinic instability test case shows problems with Lorenz grid
\item \bibentry{AL77}
\item \bibentry{AM88} \ \\
The Lorenz grid can lead to spurious Baroclinic instability. CP better

\item \bibentry{CP53}
\item \bibentry{Thu06} \ \\
Optimal configuration: $\theta$ averaaged to $(u,v)$ levels to calculate $p$. Leads to errors in the $\rho$ structure of gravity and Rossby modes but not their frequency. Then $p$ averaged to $w$ levels to compute the bouyancy term. 

Sub optimal: $\rho$ is averaged to $w$ levels. This smoothes and damps the buoyancy term leading to retardation of Rossby modes

\item \bibentry{TW05} \ \\
A height coordinate, an isentropic coordinate, and a terrain-following mass-based coordinate are considered. Minor sensitivity to advective or flux form equations. Got to have right number of DOFs. Therefore CP best and Lorenz has comp mode

\item \bibentry{Fox94} \ \\
time-vertically staggered
\item \bibentry{KA97} \ \\
blended isentropic coordinate and terrain following \\
Straightforward to use CP grid with an isentropic coordinate

\item \bibentry{Tok78} \ \\
Charney Phillips best for fixed height and $\sigma$ levels (all analysis). 

\item \bibentry{ZS03} \ \\
3 layer hurricane model. CP better than Lorenz

\end{itemize}

\nobibliography{numerics}
